STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 26, 2025
Michelle Lynn Carlton
Child Safe Michigan Judson CS
4410 W 13 Mile Rd,
Royal Oak, MI, 48073-6515
Re: License #: CB630369213
SI #: 2025SIC0000078
Dear Ms. Carlton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
***This report contains sexually explicit information***
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000078
Special Investigation Intake Date: November 4, 2024
License #: CB630369213
Licensee Group Organization: Judson CS
Licensee Designee: George Winn
Chief Administrator: Michelle Lynn Carlton
Agency Name: CHILD SAFE MICHIGAN JUDSON CS
Agency Address: 4410 W 13 MILE RD
ROYAL OAK, MI 48073-6515
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/17/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
11/4/2024 12:09 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
11/6/2024 4:00 PM Email Documentation received or sent
11/6/2024 4:16 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation

1

12/18/2024 12:29 PM Email Document received or sent
12/28/2024 4:16 PM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421.
Section (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family time for
Description each child in foster care consistent with the child's service plans,
as required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to ensure the safety
and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency has not established parenting time between the birth
parent and the children and has not explored possible relative
placements for them.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 11/4/2024 I reviewed the complaint from Complainant to
determine contact. During a telephone contact with Complainant
on 11/7/2024, Complainant reported information as reported by
Birth Mom.
Chief Administrator (CA)
On 11/7/2024 I spoke with CA by telephone related to the
allegations. CA was surprised by the allegations. She
acknowledged the agency having the children’s cases that were
mentioned in the allegations. She reported it was a new case to
the agency, and she believed the allegations to be incorrect. She
reported visits had begun between Birth Mom and the children.
She knew that to be correct because the foster care supervisor
had expressed concern about Birth Mom being very difficult during
a parent/child visit. CA reported the assigned case worker, Foster
Care Worker (FCW) is new, but FCW and the foster care
supervisor could better speak to these allegations
Birth Mom
On 11/7/2024 I interviewed Birth Mom by telephone related to the
2

complaint allegations. Birth Mom reported the Child Safe agency
just reach out to her. She is to have a visit at the agency today
and tomorrow with Child B and Child C. She said Child A is placed
with Child A’s father under the Department of Health and Human
Services (DHHS). She expressed concern that DHHS removed
her three children, had not placed her two younger children, Child
B and Child C with a relative, and that the children have had three
different workers since 10/14/2024. She clarified not all three
workers were via Child Safe because initially the children were to
be placed with Agency 1. She expressed concern the agency may
be trying to get her children adopted.
Birth Mom reported at the time the complaint came in she was
unable to get in touch with anyone. She reported given the fact
that Child Safe has set up visits for her, for now, she wants to hold
off with any complaints. She wants to see what the agency does
to service her and the children.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) & Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
On 11/7/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone. FCW was present
with Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) whom she requested to have
as a support person.
FCW reported she is new to foster care, and FCS was assisting
her, which FCS affirmed. Both she and FCS reported the agency
received Child B and Child C’s case around 10/15/2024 at which
time Child B was placed in a Child Safe family foster home. Birth
Mom was AWOL with Child C and Child C was not placed with
Child Safe until 10/18/2024. FCW reported a case transfer
meeting with DHHS was unable to occur until 10/24/2024, which
was when DHHS provided Birth Mom’s information to Child Safe.
FCW reported when they got the case there was a lot of
miscommunication, because Agency 1 thought they had the
children’s case, though, Child Safe had the family and were also
assigned the case. FCW reported after numerous emails to
DHHS, and DHHS finally creating the children placement
information in the MISACWIS system, the agency was able to
input information into the system. They also now had Birth Mom’s
information to reach out to her, which they did. FCW reported the
children would have an initial parent/child visit with Birth Mom
today (the day of this interview) and another is also set for
tomorrow. FCW reported Birth Mom also had contact with the
children on 10/19/2024.
FCW reported during the case transfer meeting with DHHS,
DHHS shared with Child Safe there was an uncle whom DHHS
3

reached out to as a possible relative placement for Child B and
Child C, but that relative was noncommittal. FCW reported DHHS
also advised them of Godmother/Fictive Kin (GMFK) who might be
interested in the children. FCW reported she contacted GMFK and
advised GMFK that DHHS was completing their clearances. She
told GMFK Child Safe would conduct a home assessment visit
with them on 11/5/2024; which she did. She reported GMFK’s
family was being explored for placement. She also reported no
adoption pursuit was occurring and a court hearing on this case is
pending for February. FCW reported the information about the
agency assessing GMFK was shared with Birth Mom, but Birth
Mom seems to want everything to happen much quicker, though
FCW explained the timeframes to her.
FCS did not dispute any information reported by FCW. She
reported she spoke with Birth Mom on 11/4/2024 and scheduled
the parenting time. The agency also had a contact scheduled with
GMFK. She reported the agency will follow through and assess
GMFK. She, as did FCW expressed no immediate concern with
GMFK, but are concerned that Birth Mom could try to take
advantage of GMFK, as per DHHS, Birth Mom has made many
threats against children service workers. FCS reported the
agency will safety plan around that.
Documentation Review:
Child B’s and Child C’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Child B (age 7) and Child C (age 2) were made temporary
court wards on 10/10/2024.
• Child B and Child C were placed in a foster home with
Child Safe on 10/15/2024 and 10/18/2024 respectively.
• Child B and Child C were placed with GMFK on
11/11/2024.
• Child A (age 16) is placed with her father under DHHS’s
direct care and supervision.
• Parent/child visitation for Birth Mom occurred on
10/18/2024, 11/7/2024, 11/8/2024, 11/11/2024, 11/13/2024,
and weekly to twice weekly thereon.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed, the evidence
does not support the allegations or the reported concerns by Birth
Mom.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code Compliance with the child protection law.
Title
4

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214
Section (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law, 1975 PA
Description 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule Violation.
Type
Allegation A concern of maltreatment against a child was brought up but the
agency did not report it or open a special evaluation.
Investigation Interviews:
On 11/19/2024 the above allegation was reported by Complainant,
and it was merged with the original complaint for its investigation
as well. During a telephone contact with Complainant on
11/20/2024, Complainant reported information as reported by Birth
Mom.
Birth Mom
On 11/20/2024 I interviewed Birth Mom by telephone. Birth Mom
reported while visiting with her children on 11/7/2024, Child C (age
2) had bruises on her inner legs and a bruise on her nose. She
said when she changed Child C’s diaper, Child C’s vaginal area
was purplish and blue. That when she wiped Child C’s vaginal
area a discharge was seen. She asked Child C if someone
touched her, and Child C said, “Daddy” touched her. Birth mom
reported when she asked FCW about what she saw on Child C,
FCW said it was a diaper rash. Birth Mom did not believe this. She
said the rash could not have occurred between 10/19/2024 and
the date of this parent/child visitation on 11/7/2024. She said
FCW had not reported the rash to her beforehand and FCW
seemed concerned when FCW saw the bruises and rash. Birth
Mom said FCW showed her a body chart for Child C, as to show
marks Child C had, but that would not explain what she saw.
Birth Mom admitted once she noticed and complained about what
she saw on Child C, the agency took Child C to the hospital for
examination. FCW took Child C to the emergency room. FCW
reported the physician said it was a diaper rash and the doctor
had no other concern. Birth Mom expressed concern that she had
wanted blood work performed on Child C and that did not occur.
Birth Mom did not report why she wanted blood work and what
she thought that would show. She acknowledged the agency told
her the doctor did not feel the blood work was necessary. Birth
Mom reported she was not allowed to go to the ER related to
Child C’s examination.
5

Birth Mom said she asked FCW if there was an investigation of
the foster parents, and FCW reported that was not required based
on the doctor’s reporting. Birth Mom reported the children were
removed and placed in another foster home, that day, on an
emergency basis as opposed to a placement with GMFK. Birth
Mom felt given her children’s situation and her concern of
maltreatment, the agency should have conducted an investigation
on the foster parents. She also felt Child B and Child C should
have been placed with her relative, GMFK immediately.
Chief Administrator (CA)
On 11/22/2024 I interviewed CA by telephone related to this
allegation. CA reported knowing Birth Mom had a concern with
Child C having a diaper rash. She reported Birth Mom has been
“complaint happy”, making various complaints. She reported Child
C was seen by a doctor about the concern.
CA reported, maltreatment by the foster parents was not why the
children were replaced. The children were replaced for their
safety. She reported when children services removed the children
from Birth Mom, Birth Mom apparently placed an “Air Tag” (a
device that helps you locate your belonging using an iPhone
application) in one of the children’s belongings, which was found.
She reported since Birth Mom had previously been on the run with
Child C and given Birth Mom’s volatility and her reporting that she
knew where the foster mother lived, the children were replaced
from that foster home for their safety.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
On 11/27/2024 I interviewed FCS about this allegation by
telephone. FCS said Birth Mom had come for her first visit with
Child B and Child C at the agency on 11/7/2024. FCS was not
present at the visit, but the FCW contacted her. FCW told her the
visit was going well until the end of the visit. At the end of the visit
Birth Mom was changing Child C’s diaper and Birth Mom began
screaming that her daughter was being sexually maltreated and
needed to be taken to the doctor. The FCW did not report the
details of what Birth Mom saw to warrant her reaction, though she
mentioned a rash. FCS advised FCW to take Child C to the
ER/Urgent Care for an examination. FCW took Child C to
Beaumont hospital, on 11/7/2024, and the examination revealed a
diaper rash. The doctor did not see any bruising or anything
related to sexual maltreatment. FCS said Birth mom was provided
this information, as well as Child C’s well child examination. FCS
affirmed that Birth Mom was not at the Urgent Care visit due to
safety concerns, but FCW exchanged text messages with Birth
6

Mom that day/evening to keep Birth Mom updated on what was
happening. FCS said Birth Mom contacted her the day after Child
C’s doctor’s visit. Birth Mom was upset, in that Birth Mom was
loud and confrontational. FCS said she tried to calm Birth Mom
down and she answered many questions Birth Mom asked about
the child and placement issues.
FCS reported Child C and Child B were replaced following the
11/7/2024 incident and concern by Birth Mom, but not due to
suspicions of maltreatment by Foster Parent 2 and Foster Parent
3. Child C had a diaper rash and a report to children service
intake or a need to conduct a special evaluation on the foster
home was not warranted. FCS explained the reason for the
children’s replacement similarly to what the CA reported. FCS
reported Foster Parent 2 had discovered a number of Air Tags in
the children’s belonging; one was discovered in Child C’s shoe.
One of the Air Tags was discovered a little before the 11/7/2024
visit, and one was discovered the day of the visit. FCS reported
they surmised Birth Mom must have placed the Air Tags on the
children’s belongings when Birth Mom was trying to avoid children
services removing the children from her care, and or when she
was on the run with Child C. FCS reported due to those Air Tags,
Birth Mom volatile behavior, and that she might know the
children’s location at the foster home, to be safe the agency
temporarily placed the children with a respite home provider until
they could finish all that was needed to place the children in
GMFK’s home. The latter of which occurred on 11/11/2024.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 12/6/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone related to this
allegation. FCW confirmed information as reported by FCS. FCW
added the following additionally information:
• While Birth Mom was changing Child C diaper Birth Mom
reported seeing a discoloration between Child C’s legs and
screamed and yelled that she wanted the police called.
• Due to Birth Mom’s behavior other staff persons stepped in
to assist in dealing with the situation. Specifically Licensing
Supervisor assisted her. Another worker called the police.
• Birth Mom told the police she wanted her child taken to the
hospital. Another worker transported Child B to a respite
home while FCW transported Child C for a medical
examination.
• She saw discoloration between Child C inner thighs, but
did not know what to make of it or of Birth Mom’s reaction.
She took Child C to Beaumont hospital and advised the
7

doctor of what she saw and the allegation by Birth Mom.
Child C was examined by two physicians and a nurse.
The physician examined Child C’s body and vaginal area.
The physician assessed Child C’s discoloration between
her inners thighs to be a rash not bruising. That Child C
had a diaper rash, and it was from chafing and her diapers.
The doctor recommended a cream. The physician had no
concern that Child C had been sexually maltreated.
• After she took Child C to the hospital, she stayed in touch
with Birth Mom on 11/7/2024 by text. Her supervisor had a
lengthy conversation with Birth mom the next day about
the hospital visit outcome, and the agency’s placement
decision for the children.
• As to Child C having other bruises, such as to her nose or
body, on 10/29/2024, the foster parent texted her that
Child C had fallen and hurt her nose. Additionally, at her
first foster home visit with the foster parents on 10/21/2024
the foster mother showed her marks Child C had on Child
C’s back shoulder and bottom. The foster mother reported
the old marks were seen when Child C was placed on
10/18/2024 and she wanted FCW to know about them.
The cause and origin of the marks were unknown. FCW
documented them on a body chart and showed that to
Birth Mom.
Licensing Supervisor (LS)
On 12/17/2024 I interviewed LS by telephone. LS reported being
present at the agency on 11/7/2024. She said FCW asked for the
licensing department’s assistance with an incident with Birth Mom
who was upset during a parent/child visitation. LS observed Child
C on a changing table with her pants pulled down. Birth Mom was
close in Child C’s face saying, “who touched you” Child C said
“yes”, at one point. When Birth Mom asked, “who touched you”
Child C did not respond, and looked startled. LS reported it was
clear to her that Child C did not understand the questions from
Birth Mom. LS said Child C is only two years old. LS reported
Birth Mom accused the foster parents of maltreatment of Child C
and said she was going to call the police. LS reported an agency
staff person called the police, but she was not sure who that staff
person was. Birth Mom said she saw bruising between Child C’s
legs, but LS said she did not see that. She saw chafing and diaper
crud. Birth Mom wanted a medical evaluation and wanted to
accompany FCW to the hospital with Child C. LS reported the
agency did not think it was safe for FCW to have the Birth Mom
accompany her. LS and FCS spoke with Birth Mom while FCW
took Child C for a medical exam. Birth Mom told them she was
8

going to refused to allow the children to go back to the foster
home or any other foster home. That the children needed to go to
the relative/fictive kin placement. LS said FCS explained to Birth
Mom why the relative/kin placement was not possible this day;
and the need for other systems (FTM, a safety plan with all
parities approvals) to be in place before such a placement could
occur.
As to a referral to children services or an initiation of a special
evaluation on Foster Parent 2 and Foster Parent 3, LS affirmed
what the other staff members interviewed had reported about Air
Tags being found in the children belongings, safety concerns for
the children and foster parents; and the agency not having
concerns or suspicion of maltreatment by the foster parents.
Documentation Review
Child C’s well child exam dated 11/5/2024 which showed:
• A normal exam. No concerns or anything unusual was
noted on the medical report form.
Child C’s medical exam from Cordell William Beaumont University
Hospital Pediatric Out Patient Clinic dated 11/7/2024 which
showed:
• The reason for the evaluation was a children service
evaluation.
• A diagnoses of diaper rash; irritant contact dermatitis,
unspecific trigger.
• The diaper rash diagnosis information form listed reasons
as to how it was diagnosed, and a list of possible causes;
none of which related to maltreatment.
• No concerns of maltreatment or anything unusual was
noted on the hospital medical form.
Child B’s and Child C’s MISACWIS case record, which showed:
• Information as documented earlier in this report.
• A social work contact for 11/4/2024 showing the agency’s
contact with Birth Mom about parent/child visitation.
• A social work contact for 11/7/2024, and a 11/7/2024
incident report showing documentation of what FCW
reported when interviewed about the parent/child visit
incident and hospital visit on 11/7/2024.
• A 10/21/2024 social work contact of FCW’s initial home
visit with the foster parent and Child B and Child C after
their initial placement and reports of the foster parent
finding an Air Tag in Child C’s shoe, the children rough
9

play/tendency to hit each other, as well as Child C’s
tendency to hit herself and pull out her hair.
• Body chart dated 10/21/2024 showing the marks to Child
C’s back and bottom and screen shot of Child C’s scratch
on her nose.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documents reviewed the
evidence does not support the allegations or a failure to report.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code Staff responsibilities.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule Violation.
Type
Allegation Allegation 1
The agency did not utilize a relative for placement of the children.
Allegation 2
The agency did not complete a trauma assessment on the
children. There is concern the worker is not working toward
reunification.
Investigation Interviews:
Allegation 1
On 11/19/2024 the above allegation was reported by Complainant,
and they were merged with the original complaint for their
investigation as well. On 11/20/2024 during a telephone contact
with Complainant, Complainant reported information as reported
by Birth Mom.
Birth Mom
On 11/20/2024 I interviewed Birth Mom by telephone about the
allegation. Birth Mom reported the agency did not immediately
seek to place her children with a relative. She reported her
children should have been placed with a relative when they were
taken from her and when the children were replaced from their
prior foster home with Child Safe, they should have been placed
10

with GMFK, not in a temporary placement. She believed the
agency was delaying placement with GMFK because they are
trying to delay reunification with her. She gave no specific reasons
or details to show evidence of this.
Chief Administrator (CA)
On 11/22/2024 I interviewed CA by telephone related to this
allegation. CA reported the foster care worker, and foster
supervisor could better speak to the allegation.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) & Foster Care Worker (FCW)
I interviewed FCS and FCW about this allegation by telephone on
11/27/2024 and 12/6/2024 respectively. As noted earlier in the
report, both FCS and FCW reported the agency was not delaying
pursuit of a relative placement. Both reported they did not have
access to possible relatives’ interest until 10/24/2024. That after
learning of GMFK interest, contact was made with GMFK, and a
home visit and assessment was initiated on 11/5/2024. They
reported Child B and Child C were unable to be placed in GMFK
care on 11/7/2024 when a respite placement occurred because
more information was needed to complete GMFK’s home
assessment, but the children were placed in GMFK care on
11/11/2024.
Allegation 2:
Complainant
On 11/19/2024 the above allegation was reported by Complainant,
and they were merged with the original complaint for its
investigation as well. On 11/20/2024 during a telephone contact
with Complainant, Complainant reported information as reported
by Birth Mom.
Birth Mom
On 11/20/2024 I interviewed Birth Mom by telephone about the
allegation. Birth Mom reported the children service worker
reported she had completed a trauma screening for Child B and
Child C, but on 10/23/2024 the judge ordered that one be
completed by the agency. Birth Mom was not clear as to whether
what had to be conducted was a trauma screening or a trauma
assessment. She reported the former was ordered and reported
the agency had not completed one. Birth Mom did not take into
the account the time required to complete an assessment
following a referral she felt the assessment should have been
completed already.
Chief Administrator (CA)
11

On 11/22/2024 I interviewed CA by telephone related to this
allegation. CA reported the foster care worker, and foster
supervisor could better speak to the allegation.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
I interviewed FCS about this allegation by telephone on
11/27/2024. FCS reported the court ordered a trauma
assessment not a trauma screening. She reported due to the
delay of Child Safe receiving the placement assignment in the
system from DHHS they were delayed in being able to generate
the referral. She reported they have had contact with the two
agencies that would likely complete the trauma assessment. She
reported given that Child C is under three, an Early on
assessment was also needed and the referral was completed by
DHHS prior to Child Safe receiving the case. FCS said contact by
Early on with the current caregiver was still pending.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
I interviewed FCW about this allegation by telephone on
12/6/2024. FCW confirmed information reported by FCS. She
reported a trauma screening for completed and the referral for the
trauma assessment was being completed this week. She said
she had discussed this matter with Birth Mom on 11/20/2024 or
11/21/2024 and she had explained the issues with the referral
delay.
Documentation Review
Child B’s and Child C’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Child B (age 7) and Child C (age 2) were made temporary
court ward on 10/10/2024.
• Child B and Child C were placed in a foster home with
Child Safe on 10/15/2024 and 10/18/2024 respectively.
• Documentation of a 10/24/2024 children service to foster
care transfer meeting.
• Child B and Child C were placed with GMFK on
11/11/2024.
• A MDHHS 5770-Relative Approval & Placement screen for
GMFK dated 11/11/2024.- showing initial clearances as of
10/22/2024; and Child Safe agency home visit with the
family on 11/5/2024.
• Trauma screening dated 10/23/2024.
• A 12/9/2024 documentation of a trauma evaluation referral.
• Copy of the court order for a court hearing on 10/23/2024
that indicated:
12

✓ Children services reported trauma screens
completed for Child B and Child C and DHHS was to
complete one for Child A.
✓ Birth Mom and the father are to participate in a clinic
evaluation.
✓ Trauma assessments are to be completed for Child
B and Child C.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence does
not support the allegations or a lack of direct work by the agency
with the children, their families, and other relevant individuals.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
February 7, 2024
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 26, 2025
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
13

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted into Child Safe Michigan Judson CS following allegations from a birth mother. The investigation covered three areas: failure to establish visitation and explore relative placements, failure to report suspected maltreatment, and failure to perform a trauma assessment while delaying relative placement. The investigation found that the agency had initiated visitation, was actively assessing a relative placement (children were placed with a godmother/fictive kin), and had no basis to report suspected maltreatment after a medical examination concluded a diaper rash was present, not abuse. The agency appropriately responded to the birth mother's concerns by taking the child for a medical exam and moving the children to a respite home due to safety concerns stemming from the birth mother's behavior and discovered AirTags, not due to suspected foster parent maltreatment. The evidence did not support any of the allegations, and no violations were established. The agency acted properly and was not found culpable for any wrongdoing.
